metaRep.metaDesc: I labeled this statement as the antecedent to function D3 because the D3 is defined by Propp as a specific quote from the cow asking not to be eaten. That quote is not in this story, but is apparently in story 100. I presume that this quote from the cow occurs between the order to kill the cow and the execution of the order.

We discussed whether the birds were essential to the bush being a "magical bush" (as Propp calls it in his description of Fvi). The fact of the bush springing out of the ground may be magical in itself, or the presence of the birds singing songs of kings and peasants may be a component of the magic.
This difficult task is not directly addressed to the hero.
Propp lists this instance as an example of epsilon1. However, epsilon3 would seem to apply more closely, since he defines it as "reconnaissance by means of other personages."

Because Propp calls story 101 a second move in general, and in his end notes says that the first move is the same as story 100, I am going to repeat the story 100 pattern before giving the 101 move listed. I'm not sure if this is the right way to handle it, so we can discuss it at the meeting.
I think the birds singing is an important part of the transformation.
Even though this instance appears chronologically before B7, we decided that it corresponds closest in time to the seeker "deciding upon counteraction."
